questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
The image shows Babcock’s forceps.

In Babcock’s forceps, the distal part of the distal blade is curved with a triangular fenestra which allows soft tissues to bulge out. The tip is non-traumatic with transverse serrations. It has a lock in the proximal part.

It is used to hold tubular structures such as parts of the bowel, fallopian tube, appendix, ureter, etc.

Option A: Allis tissue forceps have distal blades, not opposing each other. The tip has got teeth in each blade that are opposing. There is a lock in the proximal part.

It is used to hold skin flaps, fascia, aponeurosis, and the bladder wall.

Option C: Lane’s tissue holding forceps have got stout and thick distal blades with oval fenestrae. It has an opposing tooth on the tip and a lock in the proximal part.

It is used to hold bulky and tough structures and lymph nodes.

Option D: Kocher’s hemostatic forceps - It is identified by the opposing tooth on the tip and serrations in the distal blades.

It is used to hold pedicles, tough structures, and cut ends of muscles. It is also used to hold ribs during rib dissection, gauze for blunt dissection, and resected bowel.

questions.text:
For which of the following would you use the instrument shown in the image?
  1. To hold the fundus of the gall bladder 
  2. To hold a mass of hemorrhoids 
  3. To hold the cervix 
  4. To grasp the products of conception
  5. To hold the spermatic cords
questions.solution:
The image shows a sponge holding forceps. It is used to:

  • Clean skin with a swab dipped in antiseptic solution during all operations
  • Remove laminated membrane and daughter cysts during operation of hydatid cyst.
  • Hold the fundus and Hartmann’s pouch of gall bladder during cholecystectomy
  • Swab an abscess cavity
  • Hold the cervix during cerclage.

Ovum forceps is shown below. It is used to grasp products of conception and prevent the crushing of the conceptus. They have no catch and the blades are slightly bent and fenestrated. The absence of catch minimizes uterine injury if accidentally caught.

It is introduced with the blades closed and opened up inside the uterine cavity to grasp the products. The instrument is taken out with a slight rotatory movement. The rotatory movement not only facilitates detachment of the products from the uterine wall, but also minimizes the injury of the uterine wall if accidentally grasped.

Pile holding forceps are used to hold haemorrhoids.

Cord holding forceps are typically used to hold spermatic cords.

questions.text: You notice your surgery resident use the given instrument to remove gall stones. Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The above instrument is Desjardin’s choledocholithotomy forceps and is used for bile duct stone removal. It may also be used during the removal of kidney, ureteric, or bladder stones.

This is a long and slender instrument. There are finger bows but no catch. The shaft is curved. The blades are small, without serrations, and fenestrated centrally.

questions.text: For what purpose would you use the instrument shown in the image?

choices.text: To hold tough tissue like skin and fascia

questions.solution:
The above image is of Lister’s sinus forceps which are used for blunt dissection.

It is used during Hilton's method of abscess drainage to break the bacterial loculi.

It is also used for inserting or removing packing in the sinus cavity.

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
Doyen’s mouth gag is used to keep the mouth open for intraoral surgery when retraction of the tongue is not required or desirable. Mostly used for tongue surgery. It is applied on one side of the mouth on the molar teeth.

Option A: Doyen’s retractor is used to retract the abdominal wall in abdominal and pelvic surgeries to expose the field of operation.

Option C: Doyen’s intestinal occlusion clamp is used for resection and anastomosis of the intestine in cases of:

  • Strangulated hernia
  • Accidental injuries to the gut
  • Intestinal growths
  • Gastric/intestinal bypass surgeries.

Option D: Joll’s thyroid retractor is a self-retaining retractor used in thyroid surgeries to retract skin.

questions.text: Identify the instrument given in the image below:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Morris retractor with a single, flat transversely curved blade and a blunt projecting ridge with backward projection.

Morris retractor can be single or double-bladed. It is used to retract abdominal wall incisions, loin incisions, subcostal wounds or any wounds in depth.

It can be used to improve visibility on one side of an incision. Thus, it is valuable during the initial phase of a laparotomy.

Other options: 

Option A: Deaver's retractor is a question mark-shaped stout, atraumatic retractor with a broad, gently curved long blade. It is used to retract the abdominal wall and viscera. Moist mops should be kept underneath prior to placing this retractor. It is used for major abdominal surgeries, bladder surgeries and lumbar sympathectomy. 

Option C: Czerny's retractor is a superficial retractor with a thick and small blade on one side and a biflanged hook on the other side in opposite directions. It is used in hernia surgery and laparotomy, especially during closure.

Option D: Double-hook retractor consists of two hooks with a handle. It is used in excision of swellings like lipoma, neurofibroma and cyst. It is also used to hold the skin flaps when raising them.

questions.text: Which of the following instruments would be best suited to retract the liver out of the field of operation while performing an open cholecystectomy?
questions.solution:
The Deaver’s retractor would be most useful in cholecystectomy as it is specifically designed for holding the liver up and out of the way.

Deaver’s retractor is used carefully to avoid damaging the liver. Some surgeons protect the liver with an abdominal pack before placing the blade on top.

Doyen's retractor - It is used to retract the abdominal wall as well as the bladder for proper exposure of the lower uterine segment during a cesarian section.

Morris retractor is a large retractor useful for providing maximum exposure in large incisions e.g., abdominal incisions. It can be used to improve visibility on one side of an incision. Thus, it is valuable during the initial phase of a laparotomy.

Czerny's retractor - This is a double-ended retractor used to retract wound edges for intermediate-type procedures. One end has a blade with a lip which helps to retract without the edge slipping. The other end has two prongs and helps to retract the ends of an incision.

questions.text: During thyroidectomy, the given instrument was used to retract the strap muscles. Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
The above image is that of a Langenbeck retractor. It is used for holding open wounds, as in an open appendicectomy. 

Option B: Dyball retractor is used in major abdominal surgeries to retract deeper parts of the abdominal wall, bladder, or uterus while operating on the rectum and entering the rectovesical or rectouterine pouch. It has a lip at the bottom of the blade to prevent slippage. Care should be taken when it is used to retract the liver as it may damage the liver parenchyma.

Option C: Goligher retractor is a self-retaining retractor used in operations on the sigmoid colon and rectum, such as anterior resection and the upper end of abdominoperineal resection. The retractor is inserted with the side blades to separate the edges of the abdominal wall. The central blade is then inserted to keep the small bowel away from the operation site.

Option D: Travers retractor is a self-retaining retractor used for intermediate-type operations, such as:

  • Herniorrhaphy
  • Groin dissection for varicose veins
  • Femoral embolectomy.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument.
questions.solution:
The image shows Kocher’s thyroid dissector which is used during a thyroidectomy to dissect the upper pole of the thyroid.

The instrument is blunt and therefore damage to the superior thyroid artery or external laryngeal nerve is unlikely.

questions.text: What is the size of the given blade used for incision and drainage of a superficial abscess?
questions.solution:
The size of the surgical blade shown is the 11-size blade (stab knife) that has a triangular shape with an oblique edge and a sharp-pointed tip.

Uses:

  • Incision and drainage (I & D) of an abscess
  • Insertion of drains and arteriotomy.

Other options:

Option A: The 10-size blade is used for skin incisions. It has a curved cutting edge that tapers to a pointed tip.

Option C: The 22-size blade is often used for abdominal incisions. It has a flat, unsharpened back edge and a curved front cutting edge.

Option D: The 15-size blade is used for minor surgical procedures (lipoma excision) and precise skin incisions. It is a smaller blade with a small cutting edge.

questions.text: The type of knot seen in the image is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows the suture material exiting the knot is on the same side as the entry i.e no cross-over is seen. This is seen in a reef knot.

A knot is a fastening made of threads intertwined together or on themselves. Each knot consists of- 2 half-hitches placed in sequential throws. Squaring refers to tightening the knot/half-hitch in a manner that the threads lay flat due to the alternating direction of half-hitches in adjacent layers.

Types of knots:

  1. Granny knot: half-hitch over a half-hitch in the same direction. It has better-holding power than half-hitch
  2. Reef knot: half-hitch followed by a second half-hitch after squaring. 
  3. Triple throw knot: Reef knot with another half-hitch knot for added security. Knots made with prolene sutures require 6-8 throws to prevent slippage.
  4. Surgeon’s knot: Modification of the reef knot with two half-hitches in the first layer.
  5. Slip knot: Modification of either granny/reef knot formed when one end of the thread is kept taut while tightening the knot.

questions.text: A man presents to the emergency with a clean lacerated wound on his forearm. You use the given suturing technique to close his wound. Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: This technique has the least cut through rate
The wound edges should be everted
Interrupted sutures are used to approximate the wound
After the first bite, the needle should emerge at the of center the wound

questions.solution:
The given image shows interrupted sutures. Horizontal mattress sutures, not interrupted sutures, have the least cut-through rate.

In mattress suture, the initial suture is inserted as an interrupted suture, but then the needle either moves horizontally or vertically and traverses both edges of the wound once again as seen in the picture.

Continuous suture: For a continuous suture, the first suture is inserted in an identical manner to an interrupted suture, but the rest of the sutures are inserted in a continuous manner until the far end of the wound is reached.

Subcuticular sutures: Small bites of the subcuticular tissues are taken on alternate sites of the wound and then gently pulled together thus approximating the wound edges without the risk of the cross-hatched markings of interrupted sutures.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about chromic catgut?

choices.text: It is made from cat gut
It is made from rabbit gut
It is absorbed by enzymatic degradation and macrophage phagocytosis
It is tanned with nickel salts to improve handling and to resist degradation in tissue

questions.solution:
Chromic catgut is absorbed through macrophage phagocytosis and enzymatic degradation within 90 days.

It is made from collagen derived from healthy sheep or cattle. It is then tanned with chromium salts to improve handling and resist degradation in tissue.

The tensile strength lasts for 21-28 days. It has a moderate tissue reaction as compared to plain catgut, which has a high tissue reactivity.

It is used to ligate superficial vessels, suture subcutaneous tissues, and is used for stomas and other tissues that heal rapidly. It is not used in tissues that heal slowly and require prolonged support.

questions.solution:

Subcuticular sutures are used in the areas of the skin where the cosmetic appearance is important. The suture material is taken from the subcuticular layer and the edges are gently pulled together. The wound heals with minimal scarring.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented to the emergency department with an injured femoral artery following a stab injury to the right thigh. Which of the following suture materials would be ideal for the repair of the artery?
questions.solution:
Polypropylene (prolene), a non-absorbable monofilament, is the ideal suture material used for vascular anastomoses.

Vascular anastomosis requires an accurate and watertight closure. A non-absorbable material that provides tensile strength for a longer period is best suited. The material should also be non-braided to avoid platelet adherence to the suture material.

questions.text: After which procedure will you use the tube shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows Kehr’s T tube used after choledochotomy.

The horizontal limb is placed in the common bile duct while the vertical limb is brought out like a drain.

It allows bile to drain while the sphincter of Oddi is in spasm postoperatively. Once the sphincter relaxes, bile drains normally down the bile duct and into the duodenum.

Common bile duct T-tubes should remain in for 10 days. The 10-day period is required to minimize the risk of biliary peritonitis.

Once the T-tube cholangiogram has shown that there is a free flow of bile into the duodenum and that there are no retained stones, it is removed. Some surgeons like to clamp the T-tube prior to removal. Residual obstruction may be amenable to stone extraction via the T-tube.

questions.text: Which of the following are used to stop esophageal variceal bleed?
questions.solution:
All the given options can be used to stop esophageal variceal bleeding.

Image A shows the Sengstaken-Blakemore tube. It has 3 lumens - one aspiration port and 2 inflation balloons. They are:

  • Gastric aspiration port
  • Gastric balloon port
  • Esophageal balloon port

The gastric balloon is inflated and tension is applied to the gastroesophageal junction. If this does not control the haemorrhage, the esophageal balloon is inflated as well, compressing the venous plexus between them. Only gastric contents can be aspirated.

Image B shows the Minnesota tube. It has 4 openings - 2 inflation tubes and 2 suction tubes i.e. both gastric and oesophageal aspiration ports are present, which allows the aspiration of both gastric and esophageal contents.

Images C and D both show an upper GI endoscope. They are used to identify the source of bleeding and once identified, sclerotherapy and endoscopic variceal banding are performed, which have been shown to control hemorrhage effectively.

Banding has a lower rate of complications. If bleeding does not stop by banding/sclerotherapy, balloon tamponade should be tried.

questions.text: A patient has the catheter shown below inserted for draining a large liver abscess. All of the following statements are true except:

choices.text: It is a self retaining catheter
It may be introduced into the urethra to relieve bladder retention
It can be placed percutaneously through an existing nephrostomy

questions.solution:
A Malecot catheter is never introduced per-urethrally.

It is a self-retaining catheter with an umbrella or flower tip. It contains sulfur, hence is radio-opaque. It can be sterilized by boiling.

Uses:

  • Suprapubic cystostomy
  • Perinephric abscess
  • Pyonephrosis
  • Cabot’s nephrostomy
  • Subphrenic abscess
  • Cholecystotomy
  • Infected pseudocyst of pancreas
  • Amoebic liver abscess
  • Gastrostomy.

questions.text: You are an intern asked to catheterize a patient using a 16F Foley's catheter. You are unable to catheterize the patient and decide to use a slightly smaller catheter. The ward sister gives you the following four fresh catheters. Which one would you choose instead?
questions.solution:
The Foley's catheter having a green coloured ring in the ballon port is of size 14 F. If there is difficulty in catheterization, then a lower French number should be preferred.

The French scale refers to the external diameter of the catheter, and 1Fr is 0.3 mm in diameter.

Related Pearl: Foley's Catheter

A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time, it is also called an indwelling catheter.

French scale corresponds to the outer diameter in millimetres, and 1Fr is 0.3 mm in diameter.

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 18 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 18 mm and a diameter of 6 mm. 

Note:

Colour of the foleys is the colour at the baloon port as shown in the figure below

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Foley catheter?

choices.text: French in foleys catheter refers to external diameter
Silicone foleys can be kept for maximum of 2 weeks
Three way foleys is used for instrumentation
If there is peri-urethral leakage of urine after inserting a foleys, first deflating the balloon is tried

questions.solution:
French with respect to Foley catheter refers to the external diameter of the catheter, and 1Fr is 0.3 mm in diameter. 

Option B: Latex Foley catheter can be kept for one week whereas silicone Foley catheter can be kept for up to 6 weeks (some studies say 2-3 months).

Option C: Three-way Foley catheter, shown below, is used for irrigation and helps in preventing clot retention following surgeries like TURP.

Option D: If there is peri-urethral leakage of urine after inserting a Foley, inflating the balloon slightly more or using a larger-sized Foley are the corrective measures.

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
Veress needle is used to produce pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgery. 

A blunt trocar is passed through the sharp needle.

Insufflation of the abdomen is accomplished with a Veress needle held at its serrated collar with the thumb and forefinger. Since the linea alba is fused to the umbilicus, the abdominal wall is grasped with fingers or a penetrating towel clip to elevate it away from the underlying structures. 

Option A: An aneurysm needle (shown below) is used to catch small vessels and nerves.

Option C: Tracheal dilator is used to keep the tracheostomy open.

Option D: Urethral dilator is used to dilate urethra.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding laparoscopic surgery?

choices.text: Hasson approach preferred in patients with prior abdominal surgery
Monopolar diathermy is more effective in preventing electrosurgical injury
Heparin can be used routinely in irrigation fluid during laparoscopic surgery
Oral feeding can be initiated after 4-6 hours following an uneventful recovery period

questions.solution:
Bipolar diathermy is more effective than monopolar diathermy in preventing electrosurgical injury during laparoscopic surgery.

Option A: During laparoscopic surgery, an artificial pneumoperitoneum is produced by insufflation of the abdominal cavity with CO2 through a temporary port created by carefully perforating the abdominal wall and peritoneum. As a common practice, blind insertion of a Veress needle is performed to enter the peritoneal cavity.

However, in patients with prior abdominal surgeries, there is a higher chance of bowel adhesions and bowel wall injury during blind insertion of veress needle. Therefore the Hasson approach is used for direct visualization while establishing the intraperitoneal access.

Option C: Clot formation may take place during laparoscopic surgery as a result of intraoperative bleeding. The routine use of 5000–7000 units of heparin per liter of irrigation fluid helps to avoid the formation of clots.

Option D: If there is no contraindication for enteral feeding (e.g bowel resection) and no sign of ileus postoperatively, oral feeding can be initiated 4-6 hours after surgery. Initially, a liquid diet is initiated, and if well-tolerated light meals can be initiated.

questions.text: While assisting on laparoscopic cholecystectomy, you notice the given instruments are used to create a pneumoperitoneum. Select the true statement:

choices.text: Proper placement of the needle can be seen by reaspirating injected saline
It is the most widely used open technique for creating pneumoperitoneum
It involves blind puncture of the peritoneum

questions.solution:
The image is that of a Veress needle and trocar which is involved in blind puncture of the peritoneum.

There are two methods used for the creation of a pneumoperitoneum:

  1. Closed method
  2. Open method

The closed method using the Veress needle has a small but significant potential for intestinal or vascular injury on the introduction of the needle or trocar. Proper placement of the needle can be determined by the inability to re-aspirate injected saline. The normal insufflation rate is 4-6 litres/min.

The use of the open technique for creating a pneumoperitoneum avoids the morbidity related to a blind puncture.

To achieve this, a 1 cm vertical or transverse incision is made at the level of the umbilicus, stay sutures are applied, and the fascia is dissected. Free penetration into the abdominal cavity is confirmed by the gentle introduction of a finger. A Hasson trocar, shown below, is inserted and anchored, and pneumoperitoneum is created. This is the Hasson or modified Hasson approach. 

This method is preferred for patients who have undergone previous abdominal surgeries as the small bowel may be adherent to the undersurface of the abdominal wound.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument.
questions.solution:
The image shows a rectal temperature probe.

Option B: NAVA is Neurally Adjusted Ventilatory Assist is a mode of mechanical ventilation. The NAVA catheter detects electrical activity signalling on the diaphragm.

Option C: Swan Ganz catheter / Pulmonary artery catheter is used for right heart catheterization.

Option D: A CVP transducer is used in critical care settings to monitor the central venous pressure. It is connected to a central venous line and a monitor.

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The image shows a Humby's knife.

This instrument is used to harvest a split skin graft. The average thickness of the graft obtained from a Humby's knife is 0.3 mm.

questions.text: Which mode does the following waveform of cautery represent?
questions.solution:
Cutting is a mode of diathermy/electrosurgery. The cut current is a low voltage, continuous waveform. Cutting occurs when sufficient heat is applied to the tissue to cause cell water to explode into steam.

Coagulation is the sealing of blood vessels. In coagulation, a heating effect leads to cell death by dehydration and protein denaturation.

Blend is the combination of cutting and coagulation.

Fulguration refers to destructive coagulation of tissues with charring. The diathermy matching is set to coagulation and a higher effective voltage is used to make larger sparks jump an air gap thus fulgurating the tissues.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument?
questions.solution:
The given instrument is a unipolar cautery/monopolar cautery.

Other options:

Option B: The bipolar cautery contains two tips, unlike unipolar cautery which has only one tip. The current flows between these two tips and hence it does not need a return electrode, unlike the unipolar cautery.

Option C: The harmonic scalpel (shown below) is a surgical instrument used to simultaneously cut and cauterize tissue. Ultrasonic energy is used in Harmonic scalpel where ultrasonic energy is converted to mechanical energy at the active blade.

Option D: LigaSure vessel sealing system (shown below) is a bipolar apparatus for sealing vascular tissue. It applies a high coaptive pressure during the generation of tissue temperature under 1000°C, hydrogen cross-links are first ruptured and then renatured, resulting in a vascular seal that has high tensile strength.

questions.text: Which of the following is the principle behind the wound-healing procedure shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows negative pressure wound therapy using a vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) device to promote healing in chronic wounds.

Principle: An intermittent negative pressure of -125 mmHg hastens debridement and formation of granulation tissue in chronic wounds.

Indications: Chronic wounds (such as diabetic foot ulcers, stage III and IV pressure ulcers), traumatic wounds, flaps and grafts, and dehisced incisions.

Contraindications:

  1. Exposed vital structures (organs, blood vessels, or vascular grafts) 
  2. Preexisting infection 
  3. Inadequate debridement of devitalized soft tissue or bone increases the risk of infection.
  4. The presence of malignancy (Marjolin’s ulcer).
  5. An allergic reaction towards the adhesive used to maintain the vacuum seal.

Though not an absolute contraindication, there is no appreciable benefit for ischemic wounds.

questions.text: The following drain is placed after mastectomy. Identify the type of drain.
questions.solution:
The Romo Vac drain, depicted in the image, is a closed type of drain commonly used after mastectomy.

Drains are placed at surgical sites to freely collect the air or fluids that may accumulate. This enhances wound healing by preventing the formation of unnecessary cavities. Drains are prophylactic in elective surgeries and therapeutic in emergency surgeries. Drains can be -

  • Open - They are based on the principle of gravity 
  • Semi-open - Their action is based on capillary effect
  • Closed - They carry out their actions through suction

Suction drains are commonly used in chest, breast, abdominal, thyroid, and plastic surgeries. They remove intraperitoneal secretions, anastomotic leaks, and blood from hemorrhage at the surgical site. Romo Vac drain is a negative suction drain closed drain kept in the subcutaneous tissue. Romo Vac drain is indicated in modified radical mastectomy, subcutaneous swelling excision, and amputations. 

Special types of drains:

  • Chest drains are connected to an underwater seal to aid the exit of air from the pleural cavity. They are used in pneumothorax, pleural effusion, and hemothorax. 
  • After surgical exploration of the bile duct, the sphincter of Oddi goes into spasm. To facilitate drainage of bile, a T tube may be used. 

Drain insertion site care: The site of insertion of the drain is kept clean by drying and patting the drain insertion site with a clean towel after bath. The dressing is changed daily with folded gauze pieces placed below and above the drain site. 

Removal of drains: The catheter at the site is milked for residual collections. It is then clamped and the suture holding the catheter is cut. The tube is then gently pulled out and any clots at the perforation end are removed. The time of removal of drains for various conditions is as given below. 

  • Drains used in surgeries like thyroidectomy are usually removed within 24 hours. Their main purpose is to cover postoperative bleeding. 
  • In a mastectomy, a drain is placed for 5 days to collect serous collections.
  • Drains used to cover the colorectal anastomoses are placed for 5-7 days.
  • Common bile duct T-tube drains are usually placed for 10 days.
  • Drains for infections are removed when the infection subsides or when the content of the drain is minimal.

After the drain is removed, a folded gauze is placed over the drain insertion area. The dressing can be removed after 24 hours. The patient may be given an antibiotic ointment to apply over the area for a week.

questions.text: The instrument given in the image is:
questions.solution:
The given image is of a Jackson-Pratt drain.

Drains are placed at surgical sites to freely drain the air or fluids that may accumulate. They promote wound healing by preventing the formation of unnecessary cavities. Drains can be:

  • Open : They are based on the principle of gravity
  • Semi-open : Their action is based on capillary effect
  • Closed : They carry out their actions through suction

Jackson-pratt drain is a closed, air-tight drainage system that operates by self-suction. The drain is sutured in place on the skin at the site of insertion to promote stability. There are two main parts to a JP drain:

  1. Hollow tube
  2. Collection bulb

The drain should be emptied as often as possible to allow the bulb to be compressed fully in order to maintain suction. This is usually done every 4-6 hours the first few days. 

Other options:

Option A: Hemovac is also a closed type of suction drain which can typically handle larger amounts of fluid than the JP drain.

Option C: Minivac is a closed wound drainage system under negative pressure used in minor surgeries.

Option D: Corrugated drain is an open drainage system to remove excess fluid from the operated site.

questions.text:
Match the following:
  1. Urine bag
  2. Nasogastric tube
  3. Underwater seal bag
  4. Suction cannula
questions.solution:
1-B, 2-C, 3-A, 4-D is the correct option.

Urine bags are used for the collection of urine. They are usually attached to a Foley catheter placed to drain the bladder.

An underwater seal bag is used for the collection of fluid from the thoracic cavity. It acts as a one-way valve. This system allows air to leave the pleural cavity, but it cannot be drawn back in by the negative pressure that is created in the intrathoracic cavity.

Nasogastric tube/Ryle’s tube is used for nasogastric feeding/stomach wash/aspiration.

A metallic suction cannula is used to clear the operative field by suctioning secretions, blood, and fluid.

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is used for screening a 50-year-old patient with a family history of rectal cancer. Till which structure can this instrument visualize?
questions.solution:
The image shows a flexible sigmoidoscope which allows visualization till the splenic flexure. It measures 60 cm. Factors like the mobility and redundancy of the sigmoid colon can limit the extent of the examination.

Option A: An anoscope measures 8-10 cm in length and is used to visualize the anal canal.

Option B: The rigid rectoscope is useful for examination of the rectum and distal sigmoid colon. It is occasionally used therapeutically. The standard rectoscope is 25 cm in length.

Option D: Colonoscopes measure 100 to 160 cm in length and are capable of examining the entire colon and terminal ileum. Complete oral bowel preparation is necessary for colonoscopy. Sedation is required due to the duration and discomfort of the procedure.

questions.text: The position of the patient in the image shown below is known as:
questions.solution:
The above image shows a reverse Trendelenburg position, where the patient's head is elevated 15 - 30 degrees higher than the feet. It is named so, as the position is reverse of the Trendelenburg position, where the head end is lower and the feet are at a higher level.

The Trendelenburg and reverse Trendelenburg positions are used in surgeries that are required to move the abdominal viscera, such as the small bowel, away from the operative field. Restraints and sideboards are placed to prevent the patient from sliding from the bed.

In laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the patient is placed in a reverse Trendelenburg position slightly rotated to the left. This exposes the fundus of the gallbladder which is retracted towards the diaphragm.

Other options: 

Option A: Lloyd Davies's position is a 30-degree Trendelenburg position with the hips flexed at 15 degrees. It is used for rectal and anal canal surgeries like low anterior resection and abdominoperineal resection. It can cause compartment syndrome of the calves.

Option B: Jackknife position is a modified prone position where the patient's hips are supported on a pillow and the table is flexed at a 90-degree angle with the head and feet at a lower level. It is not used anymore due to the chest compression causing impaired ventilation leading to positional asphyxia. It was used for hemorrhoids and fissure surgery.

Related Pearl: Eponyms named after Friedrich Trendelenburg

  • Trendelenburg sign: This sign is demonstrated by asking the patient to stand on one limb. When the patient stands on the affected limb, the pelvis severely drops over the swing limb. This is seen in the paralysis of gluteus medius and minimus, dislocated hip, fracture neck of femur
  • Trendelenburg gait: This gait is seen in patients with Trendelenburg sign. The body swings to the opposite side every time when the weight is borne on the same side. 
  • Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's head is lower than his feet (head-down position)
  • Reverse Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's feet are lower than his head (head-up position)
  • Brodie Trendelenburg test: It is a test for presence of incompetent valves in lower limb.

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding robotic surgery?

choices.text: It is associated with less blood loss compared to laparoscopic surgery
Robotic surgery cuts down the operating time significantly
The learning curve is longer with robotic surgery
It is associated with a shorter length of hospital stay

questions.solution:
Even though robotic surgery has multiple advantages, the operating time is increased significantly compared to laparoscopic or open surgery.

Advantages of robotic surgery include:

  1. 3D vision
  2. Tremor reduction
  3. Scaling of movements
  4. Finer dissection and suturing
  5. Less intraoperative bleeding
  6. Reduction in the length of hospital stay
  7. Reduction of wound complications

Disadvantages of robotic surgery include:

  1. More expensive than other minimally invasive procedures
  2. Longer operative time
  3. Longer learning curve
  4. Loss of tactile feedback
